articles.headline: News Media Feel Limits to Georgia’s Democracy
articles.snippet: Georgia’s critics cite a lack of press freedom as an example of the shortfalls in the country’s democratic standards.
articles.abstract: Georgia’s critics cite a lack of press freedom as an example of the shortfalls in the country’s democratic standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia  The cameras at Georgia’s main opposition broadcaster, Imedi, kept rolling Nov. 7, when masked riot police officers with machine guns burst into the studio. They smashed equipment, ordered employees and television guests to lie on the floor and confiscated their cellphones. A news anchor remained on-screen throughout, describing the mayhem. Then all went black.
articles.byline: By Dan Bilefsky and Michael Schwirtz

articles.headline: If This Won’t Kill the Bonus, What Will?
articles.snippet: With the rapid reshaping of the financial industry over the past month, calls to rein in executive compensation may become louder than ever.
articles.abstract: With the rapid reshaping of the financial industry over the past month, calls to rein in executive compensation may become louder than ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIGHT away, Henry A. Waxman lit into Richard S. Fuld Jr. on the one issue that most inspires a passionate debate: executive compensation.

articles.headline: The Street’s Emergency Responders
articles.snippet: Beginning late last year, bankers and lawyers in the specialized business of advising financial firms have been in high demand.
articles.abstract: Beginning late last year, bankers and lawyers in the specialized business of advising financial firms have been in high demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON Sept. 6, Fannie Mae’s board of directors convened at the behest of senior government officials, who informed them that, essentially, the mortgage finance giant would be taken over.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: In ‘Sweetie’ and ‘Dear,’ a Hurt for the Elderly
articles.snippet: Studies find that speaking to older people in the belittling style known as elderspeak can have health consequences.
articles.abstract: Studies find that speaking to older people in the belittling style known as elderspeak can have health consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: Professionals call it elderspeak, the sweetly belittling form of address that has always rankled older people: the doctor who talks to their child rather than to them about their health; the store clerk who assumes that an older person does not know how to work a computer, or needs to be addressed slowly or in a loud voice. Then there are those who address any elderly person as “dear.”

articles.headline: Global Fears of a Recession Grow
articles.snippet: Three days after the approval of the White House’s $700 billion rescue plan, it looks like a pebble tossed into a churning sea.
articles.abstract: Three days after the approval of the White House’s $700 billion rescue plan, it looks like a pebble tossed into a churning sea.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When the White House brought out its $700 billion rescue plan two weeks ago, its sheer size was meant to soothe the global financial system, restoring trust and confidence. Three days after the plan was approved, it looks like a pebble tossed into a churning sea.

articles.headline: Campaigns Shift to Attack Mode on Eve of Debate
articles.snippet: John McCain turned toward a more negative tone, and the Obama campaign signaled it would respond in kind.
articles.abstract: John McCain turned toward a more negative tone, and the Obama campaign signaled it would respond in kind.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain and Senator Barack Obama entered their general election contest this summer denouncing American politics as trivial and negative, and vowing to run campaigns that would address the concerns of voters during a difficult time.

articles.headline: A Day (Gasp) Like Any Other
articles.snippet: This crisis doesn’t wear you down over time. It hits you over the head with a two-by-four on a daily basis.
articles.abstract: This crisis doesn’t wear you down over time. It hits you over the head with a two-by-four on a daily basis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is it ever going to end?

articles.headline: Emerging Markets Find They Aren’t Insulated From the Tumult
articles.snippet: Emerging markets took one of their biggest collective tumbles in a decade as stock markets from Mexico to Indonesia to Russia were gripped by fears of a collapse.
articles.abstract: Emerging markets took one of their biggest collective tumbles in a decade as stock markets from Mexico to Indonesia to Russia were gripped by fears of a collapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO  Emerging markets took one of their biggest collective tumbles in a decade Monday as stock markets from Mexico to Indonesia to Russia were gripped by fears of a collapse of Europe’s banking system and concern that a global recession could drag down the price of commodities, forcing a steep slowdown in emerging-market growth.

articles.headline: Impartiality of S.E.C. Is Questioned
articles.snippet: An inquiry concluded that the Securities and Exchange Commission should consider disciplining staff members for their role in an insider trading investigation.
articles.abstract: An inquiry concluded that the Securities and Exchange Commission should consider disciplining staff members for their role in an insider trading investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal inquiry has concluded that the Securities and Exchange Commission should consider disciplining its director of enforcement and two supervisors for their role in handling an insider trading investigation that led to the firing of an S.E.C. lawyer for trying to interview an influential Wall Street executive.

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Finds Itself on Defense
articles.snippet: The Citadel Group of Chicago, the giant hedge fund that Kenneth C. Griffin has run successfully for nearly 20 years, is leaking money.
articles.abstract: The Citadel Group of Chicago, the giant hedge fund that Kenneth C. Griffin has run successfully for nearly 20 years, is leaking money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kenneth C. Griffin was one of those Wall Street whiz kids. As a teenager, he traded out of his dorm room at Harvard. In his 20s, he opened his own hedge fund. In his 30s, he boasted that his company might one day rival Goldman Sachs.

articles.headline: U.S. Markets Plunge Despite Hint of Rate Cut
articles.snippet: Wall Street extended its heavy losses on Tuesday despite reassurances from the Fed chairman that the central bank was prepared to lower interest rates.
articles.abstract: Wall Street extended its heavy losses on Tuesday despite reassurances from the Fed chairman that the central bank was prepared to lower interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The promise of lower interest rates and new federal efforts to stem the financial crisis failed to dispel the fear gripping Wall Street on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Iceland, in a Precarious Position, Takes Drastic Steps to Right Itself
articles.snippet: In addition to seeking a $5.5 billion loan from Russia, Iceland pegged its currency to an index and took control of one of its largest banks as it struggled to keep its economy afloat.
articles.abstract: In addition to seeking a $5.5 billion loan from Russia, Iceland pegged its currency to an index and took control of one of its largest banks as it struggled to keep its economy afloat.
articles.lead_paragraph: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — The government of Iceland took extraordinary measures on Tuesday to stave off “national bankruptcy,” as the credit crisis tightened its grip on this remote island nation in the North Atlantic.
articles.byline: By Eric Pfanner and Julia Werdigier
